Name: Mrs. Sarah Waddingham
Address: Battle Lake
Birthplace: Norway, the Ost, born 1870

1. **PIONEER HISTORY**
   - What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1896
   - Where did you set up homesteading? Mybroy, Sask
   - Where had you been living before that? Battle Lake
   - For how many people did you propose homestead? 4 adults
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 4 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, syrup, honey, salt, pepper, yeast, soda, baking powder

2. **FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS**
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Golden's
   - In what quantities did you buy it? About 100 lbs
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
   - How much did you use Graham flour? Not enough
   - Whole wheat flour?
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes, far away? No, what year? 1910
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Not sure
   - What other grain products did you use? Oats, cornmeal, buckwheat, flour
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, later
   - How did you grind it? By hand mill and small crusher

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs. and 200 lbs. by the pound.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? About $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwardsburg.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb. browned.

At what price? Don't remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From local cows.

Butter? Made own butter.

Eggs? Had hens and got own eggs.

What was the price of butter? 10 cents.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork and beef.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchered our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? Butchered in the fall.

How did you preserve meat? Cured the pork and canned beef.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not in early days.

If so what year was it organized? Around 1912.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Turkey and chicken.

For how long? Ten seasons.

What part did fish play in the family diet? More while in spring.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Some fresh, some cured.

Kinds? Suckers, Jack fish, pickerel.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Wheat porridge brown sugar milk & cream
Toast eggs Some times meat syrup
Dinner potatoes meat Vegetables pie or pudding
Supper fried potatoes meat or eggs fruitcake

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the date, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Mrs. Casswell and 2 children
Roast beef potatoes vegetables plum pudding
bread crustie butter tea, as long as I was on the farm we had Christmas dinner and supper we usual had 12-16 guests then was some children we had 3 of our own 2 Boys 1 Girl all married now

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

One year we were often short of money we always had lots to eat meat bread vegetables and some fruit tea sugar

The women in our area were hard to Remember
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest years. (Give dates here possible.)

Breakfast: Wheat porridge, bacon, sugar, orange juice.

Lunch: Eggs, some times cheese & grapefruit.

Dinner: Potatoes, peas & vegetables, pie or pudding.

Supper: Fried potatoes, bread & applesauce.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

As long as I was on the farm I continued to make my own bread, butter, raise fowl, sell egg and butter. Later years we sold cream had an ice well could keep the cream sweet.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back or page if more space is needed).

I will tell you about my parents they came from Ont in 1885 homesteaded in the Carlyle district drove from Moosemin over 60 miles with horses drew lumber for a log house for floor and roof got the logs out of those mountains we sent out for groceries to Portage la Prairie got brown sugar by barrel no fruit the first years bought sugar by barrel no fruit the first years bought corn polished butter in tubs and sold at Moosemin till the railroad came to Carlyle my parents brought later the railroad came to Carlyle my parents brought 6 of their family of 11 one son was here before them and a daughter came after I am the only one that is left here. My Brother in Niche and I am '86 past you will understand it is hard to Remember.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

As long as I was on the farm I continued to do as much as I could. We raised our own eggs and cream. We had an ice well and kept the cream.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and observing foods in other ways. Include prices, problems or stories that illustrate the situation.

I will tell you about my parents they came from out in 1885 homesteaded in the Castle Rock district above from Missouri over 60 miles with horses drawn lumber for a log house for floor and roof. Got the logs off for one dollar a load or send oil for processing. Co-opage was scarce and brown sugar by barrel or barrel. The first years bought and packed both in tubs and sold at $1.00 a barrel.

The railroad came to Ogden and Placerville and the town grew. Before then it was a small town.
